_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Energy Transfer LP
Red Lake Gas Plant
Stanton, Texas

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
FOR 
THE RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN (RMPlan)

Introduction and Policies
Energy Transfer LP is committed to managing all operations in a manner that protects the environment and the health and safety of employees, customers, contractors and the public while fully complying with applicable laws and regulations.  Energy Transfers management philosophy goals are achieved through the implementation of the Environmental, Health, and Safety Management Systems, by the personal commitments of employees and contractors, and by open communication with employees, customers, neighbors, and regulators. 
The purpose of this Risk Management Plan (RMP) is to provide information about operations at the facility, programs to prevent accidental chemical releases, emergency planning and response activities in the event an accidental release should occur, the five-year accident history of the facility, and continuous improvement efforts to improve safety at the facility.
This submission is being sent to EPA as required by 40 CFR 68.190(b)(5), which requires an RMP update due to a revised hazard review.  The revised hazard review incorporates Train 2 into the Train 1 hazard review.
Non-Responding Stationary Source and Regulated Substances
Energy Transfer owns and operates a natural gas processing plant located near Stanton, Texas.  The Red Lake Gas Plant treats and dehydrates natural gas to produce residue gas (methane) and natural gas liquids (NGL).  After processing, the residue gas and NGL exit the plant via product pipelines. 
The incoming raw field gas/hydrocarbon liquids mixture enters the facility and flows into a slug catcher.  Gas exits the slug catcher and is routed to a three-phase separator.  The gas is then treated to remove hydrogen sulfide (H2S), carbon dioxide (CO2), water, and excess nitrogen before being sent to the cryogenic processing unit.  In the cryogenic unit, sub-zero temperatures separate the natu

ral gas liquids and residue sales gas (methane).  Propane is used as a refrigerant in this process.  The chilled dehydrated gas is then sent to a demethanizer tower where it is separated into the residue gas product stream and the NGL product stream.  Both products leave the facility via pipeline.
Hydrocarbon liquids from the slug catcher and the three-phase separator are routed to a stabilizer.  In the stabilizer, water, light-end vapors, and other impurities are removed.  Natural gas liquids are then routed to the liquid amine treater where H2S and CO2 are removed.  The treated NGL leaves the facility via pipeline.
Waste gas (H2S and CO2) are routed to a thermal oxidizer.  Condensate and wastewater (slop) from the various process separators, dehydration unit, cryogenic unit, and scrubbers are routed to storage tanks.  Condensate and slop are periodically loaded into tank trucks for outside sales and/or disposal.
The RMP flammable substances and mixtures stored or processed at the facility are the flammable mixture comprised of methane, ethane, propane, isobutane, butane, isopentane, and pentane, which is being processed through the plant; as well as propane, which is used as refrigerant in the cryogenic process. There are no toxic substances present at the facility in amounts greater than threshold quantity.  Hydrogen sulfide, the only RMP toxic substance found in the process, is stored in quantities far below the RMP threshold quantity (documentation of amounts stored is found in the documentation section of the RMP binder).  
Energy Transfer has determined that the gas plant should be considered one process under the RMP rule.  This facility has one process (as defined by the regulation) consisting of a flammable mixture and propane.  Although the systems containing the flammable mixture and the propane are not interconnected, an incident in one of the systems could trigger a release in the other system, therefore, the two systems should be considered one proces

s (see definition of process at 40 CFR 68.3). 
Energy Transfer has determined that the Red Lake Gas Plant -Train 1 and Train 2 is classified as a Program Level 1 facility under the RMP regulation because the nearest public receptor is beyond the worst-case scenario flammable endpoint and the facility has not experienced an accidental release that caused offsite impacts.  As required by the RMP rule for Program Level 1 facilities, response actions have been coordinated with local emergency planning and response agencies.  
Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
The accidental release prevention and emergency planning and response programs in place at the facility include:
-	Operating in compliance with required environmental permits and regulations. 
-	Operating and maintaining assets in such a manner that unintentional releases are minimized.
-	Operating and maintaining assets in such a manner that the small releases associated with normal operation and maintenance will be minimized to the extent possible.
-	Correcting non-compliance found by regular audits of the facility, operator training, and intervention.
Prevention Program
The Red Lake Gas Plant is operating under a prevention program that involves identifying and taking steps to avoid potential accidental chemical releases.  A few examples of the prevention features implemented at this Program Level 1 facility include:
-	Providing overpressure relief valves on pressurized vessels.
-	Providing level transmitters and alarms on vessels to help prevent overfilling.
-	Minimizing the possibility of an interruption in the combustion of hydrocarbon vapors by having a continuous flare.
-	Providing automated and manual valves to isolate portions of the process.
-	Installing hydrocarbon gas detectors throughout the gas plant to alarm personnel of a possible explosive environment.
-	Installing fire eye detectors throughout the gas plant to alarm personnel of a possible fire.
-	Installing security

lighting to facilitate observation of the entire facility.
-	Minimizing the possibility of emergencies by manning the facility 24/7/365.
-	Providing an evacuation alarm system to safely evacuate the facility during an emergency.
-	Conducting periodic operational rounds to ensure problems are detected and corrected in a timely manner.
	Five-Year Accident History
	No incident resulting in onsite injuries, death or significant property damage or known offsite impacts, such as death, injury, property damage, shelter in place, evacuation, or environmental damage from a regulated substance has occurred at the facility within the last five years.
	Emergency Planning and Response Program
	The facility will conduct emergency response preparedness activities and coordinate any emergency response actions necessary with the Martin County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) and the Martin County Volunteer Fire Department.  Also involved in emergency response for the facility will be the Martin County Sheriffs Department.  The Plant Management is responsible for coordinating the emergency actions when an incident occurs within the facility.  An emergency response program is in place at the facility and that program has been coordinated with local officials.  The Red Lake Gas Plant is designated as a non-responding stationary source.  The emergency planning and response program provides the essential information for effectively protecting workers, the public, and the environment during emergency situations.  
	Continuous Safety Improvement Efforts
	Energy Transfers Environmental, Health, and Safety Management System forms the framework for continuous safety improvement.  Some of the key components are: 
-	The Management of Change provisions ensure that the potential safety and health impacts of any change made to process chemicals, technology, equipment or procedures are considered.
-	The Hazard Review provisions serve as a tool to ensure timely evaluation of potential ha

zards, thereby leading to continual improvements in safety standards.
-	The Mechanical Integrity provisions ensure that process equipment and instrumentation are designed, constructed, installed and maintained to minimize the risk of hazardous releases, thereby serving as an integral part of the safety program.
-	Incident Investigation procedures are in place to ensure that corrective and/or preventative measures are taken, as applicable, following an incident.  This ensures that process design, operating equipment, and operating and maintenance safe work practices are evaluated to determine changes needed to prevent recurrence of the incident.
-	Internal and third-party compliance audits will ensure that the level of safety protection at the facility is periodically evaluated for improvements with any action items tracked to completion.
-	An ongoing dialogue with the Martin County LEPC and the Martin County Volunteer Fire Department will ensure a readiness to respond to any potential emergencies, as well to implement improvements as the need develops.
